Your videos have been a part of my life since you began your journey with YouTube, and as a transgendered individual, you inspired me to live my truth. I just want to say that I am proud of you. I am proud of all that you have achieved in life, and all that you continue to achieve. You always go out of your way to lift others up. Your family should be honored by that invitation. You are worthy of love. Worthy of respect, and it makes me cry to see you so hurt by all of this. I can only imagine how you are feeling. Congratulations on your marriage. Please be safe. Live your truth. Biggest of hugs!
- Zephrey Cookson

snippet.textDisplay:
To watch you reminds me of a time in my life when I went through the same thing. My father left when I was 6 months old and I chose to reconnect when I was 19. I was warned about him, his abusive and manipulative behaviour and the fact that nothing good would come of it. I still chose to reconnect because I knew deep down I had a yearning. I may not be a Jehovah's witness or understand anything from that but what I can connect to is the blatant hurt and pain you're feeling. I won't share my whole story here but it did not end well. I had a good couple years with him, getting to know him, reconnecting, learning and sharing stories but ultimately told I was never wanted, not wanted now and how my sister and I had ruined his life. As a child, it is NOT your responsibility to take on their hate, their mistakes, their regrets. As a child, you are only worthy of love, compassion and care. After a long on and off period, I decided that he wasn't deserving of coming to my wedding. He did not approve of my husband because it showed him what a great man is. He could never relate to me because I was the splitting image of him and he hated the fact that unlike all the women in his life, I was not submissive to his abuse. It hurt but I healed. It has been years and I still think of him from time to time. Feelings of guilt and sadness will overcome you, it is not something that will ever really heal but for your mental health, your happiness and the future of yourself, do what is best for you and let go. P.S. I've been married for 3 years in June and there is not one day I regret not having him at my wedding. It is YOUR time for love and happiness, don't have anyone there that does not share that.
Sending you all the love in the world and I cannot wait to watch your marriage bloom. Xxx sending love from South Africa

snippet.textDisplay: I know a small piece of what you are feeling, my father chose not to come to my wedding because I wanted both him and my stepdad to walk me down the aisle but he couldn't put his problems aside and be there for ME! It hurts a deep deep spot in your heart that doesn't really heal. He since apologized but I think about it often and ive been married for almost 10yrs. Even though he hasn't really been a big role in my life ever I love my dad so much, the need for him to love me more than his wife is hard. But I keep it inside and have since created a little family with my husband and refuse to ever have my children feel like a burden that I have felt but was confused when I was younger. ❤️ Hang in there

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you, Hannah. Thank you. Thank you for your vulnerability and bravery, as we all know the risks involved with posting this. You are so brave, and you absolutely did the right thing. Staying true to yourself is so important, and whether you’re related by blood or not, toxic is toxic. Period. You don’t deserve to be subject to this, and I’m so sorry that religion has driven you apart from your father, even though it’s not what you wanted. Children come first, always, and I feel that’s parenting 101. Unconditional love is what we all deserve, and although those of us that encompass your following can’t replace your dad, know that you are unconditionally loved and supported by MILLIONS of us. We will celebrate you and Ella, genuinely, no questions asked.

You’re absolutely right in saying and believing that you have nothing to be ashamed of. You found love, a partner in life, someone to be your best friend and person forever. The one you love is supposed to be your best friend, parent, sibling, all in one. I hope you take comfort in knowing that Ella, your friends, your internet friends, remaining family, and kitties have nothing but infinite love for you. You can always count on that ❤️

snippet.textDisplay:
"Why am I surprised? Why am I upset?"
As someone who has constantly strived for 30 years to make my father proud of me, and still try even after being disowned by both parents, I can answer that for you
Because in the end he's your father. And even though you knew the answer before even bringing it to his attention, you had hoped that somewhere deep down inside, he wouldn't be selfish this time and put his child, YOU at the forefront. But he didnt. And it hurts.
And even though you knew this, it is a normal reaction to be upset and hurt. After all, that is your father.
But you are also right in saying that someone who doesn't support you and love you for who you are and who you love shouldn't be there.
Sometimes doing what's best for us is hard and has some tough feelings to feel, but with time comes healing and better things. ❤

When I left I had to start over from the bottom. It’s difficult and I wish it on no one. It’s really sad that my family is brainwashed by the JW teachings. I haven’t heard from them in 6 years.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm only 51 seconds into the video but I needed to stop and say thank you for being so open and honest with us. I don't really have anyone to turn to about my problems so when I do let go to people it sounds like I'm just complaining. My life to others doesn't seem bad but on the inside I'm lost in an endless maze. I don't really have an ending point and I don't want to complain because I know it could all be so much worse (from my own past experience) but I needed to open up. Thank you Hannah.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm not surprised you care. snippet.textDisplay: Oh sweet girl! My heart breaks for you in this video. I've been disappointed by my relationship with my father so many times. And I've asked the same question. Why does it still hurt? It hurts because we still love them and we're holding on to the hope that one day they'll change. My dad isn't part of a cult so I can't understand the deep hurt that comes from that factor. Don't lose that hope, Hannah! You and he still have many years together on this Earth and maybe one day he'll see the light. Think of how beautiful that could be. My dad is just now starting to change and it's honestly weird and hard to understand, because I still expect his angry reactions and disappointment. But he's finally starting to see me clearly instead of through the black and white view of who he expects me to be. Hang in there, beautiful!

snippet.textDisplay: I didn't know you were raised a JW...same here and my JW mother will not talk to me simply for leaving.  I was not disfellowshipped either.  If people cannot wrap their heads around that Jehovah's Witnesses is a dangerous Cult then it's on them...and I get it, people don't understand the term Cult very well.  But to desert their own child for the sake of surviving their Doomsday teachings, there's a serious issue.  Back in the '90s when I was still a JW, it was still the same as today; the world could end tomorrow.  The horrible death if you're not a JW.  Being taught such traumatic teachings every day as a child really messes with anyone's mind permanently.    In either case, I'm very sorry to hear about your father :(  Much love!

snippet.textDisplay: Wow, Hannah, thank you.  I am an ex-Witness and I am a lesbian.  It took over 15yrs for me to decide that I could not continue living a lie as a Witness and to accept that I was gay.  I was 44 yrs old when I came out because I finally accepted that there was nothing I could do about it.  It is the reality many of us face.  I have no hard feelings toward them because I understand it is one way or the other with JW's.  You either embrace their beliefs in their entirety or not.  Unfortunately, your dad thinks he is honouring God by disowning you.  That doesn't make it easier I know, but please, draw strength from the fact that you are not at fault, you are simply you, living your truth as best you can.  Surround yourself with love, you will get through this. xox

snippet.textDisplay:
I am all too familiar with the helpless fury of watching a parent succumb to the powerful and exclusionary groupthink of the JWs.
I’ve lost my dad to them- I’ve had hope for too long and been disappointed over and over again. I still have hope for my little brothers, who know me as an apostate, but I can only love and support them with all of my heart because they are wonderful, smart kids who deserve more opportunity than what their narrow-minded, brainwashed parents can afford them. I also need to be there for them because if they EVER choose to leave, or maybe come out as gay, their religion actively encourages their family, friends and wider community to shun them. This is documented in the Watchtower- and this detail is the only reason I agree that the JW church is indeed a cult. If there are negative consequences to choosing to defect, that there is a CULT, no question about it.
You are incredibly brave and strong to be so vocal about this- I know the pain of trying to tiptoe around this elephant in the room to maintain the peace. Your father is missing out on the wonderful experience of being there with you by his choice, you did nothing wrong and are more complete a person than he will ever be able to be.

snippet.textDisplay: THIS. This is by far the best and most relatable video on the internet. This doesn't have to do with being gy, lesbian, whatever. This is about parents. This is about how they SHOULD love us and instead DO NOT. I was raised by a single mom. Adopted. And she was a 'narcissistic parent.' I grew up sick, grinding my teeth every night, scared, nervous, upset, alone, lonely, a hopeless romantic, you name it. When I met my husband I learned how she was was TOXIC. everyday that my husband and I hung out when we dated she made me feel guilty, bad, selfish you name it. And tbh I was happy. I was in love. I was becoming an adult. Doing adult things adult this didn't "fit or work' for her lifestyle and goals. She flat out told me that she wanted me to stay and never leave. Never have a life. Well, I went no contact for the last 2 years of her life. I married, had a child, a home and a life. I finally did my own thing. I finally became a woman. Loved, not scared and nervous. I realized why I was why I was. I realized I deserved so much. When she passed away I had 0 regrets that we didn't talk. That we didn't "make up" going NO CONTACT is OKAY with your parents. We owe them nothing. Nothing. We deserve love and sometimes parents aren't it. Find it within yourself, find it yourself and then you will heal. Ty Hannah for this video. It was BRAVE AF. Bold. Truthful. YAS. Love you girl. Always have. Proud of you. SO PROUD.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wish I could rate this with hearts rather than thumbs.

I had a similar experience with family not coming to my wedding -- or at least, not bringing their children -- because of their "beliefs" and my "lifestyle". It wasn't cult related in my case. It hurt a lot and I wound up disinviting most of the family because they supported that person over me and some told me they'd have done the same, and I didn't speak to most of my family for years after that.

Weddings are family occasions. They are times when families are supposed to come together to support and celebrate the couple. That's supposed to happen regardless of whether they completely get along at other times. It's not the time for bullshit, it's the time to pull your head out of your butt and be there for your loved one. When that fails to happen, it HURTS because it is genuinely fucked up.

I didn't go to my daughter's wedding, not because I didn't want to, but because I thought she didn't want me there, and I wanted to respect her wishes even though it broke my heart. Later I realized that she probably did actually want me there, but there was really bad communication between us (there still is, as much as I'd do anything to fix that, and I may never really know what was in her head at the time). I will regret missing her wedding for the rest of my life.

The upshot... OF COURSE you care. He's your father. You'll always care. I wish I could tell him for you as a parent, that he'll regret this. But I can't, and he's not likely to change right now. So I hope you'll be able to focus on all the people who ARE choosing YOU on your wedding day and enjoy your wedding to the fullest on that day.

snippet.textDisplay:
I can relate to this story.
I didn't grow up religious, but my father was emotionally and verbally abusive starting at 8 years old (for me). He was an attorney and shifted into domestic violence, and when trauma memories from his childhood resurfaced he refused to seek therapy or change out of DV so he slowly became the very thing he was fighting against. I haven't talked to him for three years, and everything in my gut tells me not to let him back into my life. But then I think about my future wedding, how I'd want him to walk me down the aisle and dance with me. The dreams of the happy little girl I used to be, watching TLC weddings and cuddling with him on the couch. I have to keep reminding myself that the man I knew has been replaced by an imposter and I can't trust him, and that hurts so bad.

snippet.textDisplay:
I understand how this feels. If I ever decide to get married, neither of my parents will be there. Both of them are heavy drug users, alcoholics and were either totally absent in my life or very abusive. When I turned 18 I separated myself completely and haven't had any contact for many years.
Sometimes when Im talking to my boyfriend about the possibility of getting married, it breaks my heart a little. His whole family would be there in a heartbeat, but mine?

I think what hits me most is I wont have anyone to "give me away". Not in the traditional sense of "here's my daughter now you own her" but in the sense of "i cared for this person and raised them their whole life and i hope now you can do the same."

Besides very short intervals in my life where I stayed with friends or relatives, I completely raised myself. I dont have anyone to walk me down the aisle. Im walking myself. And for some reason the thought of that is extremely painful to me.

snippet.textDisplay:
I feel like there's some similarity between JW and LDS. I felt like people put this entity before people I love and myself. The church made me believe in things that I didn't believe in. It brainwashed me into changing my values and morals. I was devote and it wasn't until I got older that I was able to question more and I distanced myself. I'm so glad I left and have chosen morals and value that I have fostered and wholly believe in. I don't want to even imagined what I would have lost had I stayed. Now, I only wish they would stop bothering me and following me.

In summary, it was toxic staying and I'm glad to have left. Besides the point, hopefully, more joyful announcements are to come concerning the wedding and I wish you the best. I hope you find love and support elsewhere. Although it hurts now those who love and support you will be there that day.

snippet.textDisplay:
My dad has also cut me off at multiple times for choices that I have made. He is ultra catholic. I was raised ultra catholic. Catholicism almost feels like a cult. I never felt any sort of connection to the church. In fact, I was always completely disgusted by it. I have so many issues with my identity and my sex life because of the things that were beat into my head as a child. I moved in with my boyfriend when I was 19, because we were ready to start a life together, and I feel like I couldn't marry someone until I know for a fact that I can live with them. How do you truly know someone unless you see them in every situation in the place that they feel most comfortable? Obviously, my dad did not like this. He casted me out, called me a sinner, condemned me to hell for "shacking up." He had told me all of my life that if I didn't get married in the church he would not be at my wedding. He has reminded me this time and time again over the past year. It is the worst feeling in the world.


I eventually gathered the strength to tell him to fuck off if he was going to fill my life with negativity, and that when he was ready to accept me and the decisions I am making he can reach out. We haven't really spoken about it since.


It is the hardest thing to make the choice to cut your parent out of your life. However, I truly believe that, no matter what, no matter who they are to you, a toxic person is a toxic person. It is OKAY and completely acceptable to put yourself first. You must. All that matters is you and Ella. That you guys are happy and healthy for each other.


I'm proud of you. I love you. Good job. Congratulations. I look foreword to seeing all of the wedding stuff <3

snippet.textDisplay: I remember when my baby sister came out at school (a religious private school), we expected back lash. But it was still shocking. My husband is Greek Orthodox, and I became that to marry him. I was raised Catholic. My daughters partner is transgender. I love my daughter, I love my future son in law, and I love and completely adore their children. They are a family, and they are MY family and I made that clear to everyone in law wise in my life and no one, not one person saw them as less than, let alone treated them as such. They were gathered into the family fold with as much love as I have for all of them and I wouldnt have it any other way and I dare anyone to.treat them badly or ignore them.

You ARE special, you ARE worthy of love, and you ARE normal. I dont care who said what about you. And I dont know you, but I'm sending all my love to you and your future wife.

Man this really hit home for me. I'm so sorry. I haven't seen my father in person since I was a teenager. I'm now about to be 25. He chose christianity over me. Shunned me and even followed me down the street as I tried to get away from him saying things like "two women and a child isnt a family" or that I was just an abomination in general. He followed me for blocks shouting things at me. That was the last time I've seen him in person. I will never forget that. Ever in my life.

I know how you feel when you said you didnt know why you felt sad. You knew it was coming. Even to this day I still feel sad about my father choosing a religion over me. But time does heal. And I wish you nothing but the best girl. Love you 💙

My heart aches for you Hannah. My birth father isn’t religious, yet he abandonned me when I was 4 and never ever tried to contact me. Then I found out from a friend that he stole all my Facebook photos and put them on his wall saying I was his kid.

I wanted to love him but I couldn’t. Trying to contact him would be destructive to me and it has taken me years to come to terms with my decision to cut all his family out of my life.

This kind of wound never goes away, it just becomes more bearable and it sucks all the time.

I truly hope you have an amazing wedding, an amazing marriage, and an amazing life. You deserve to be happy Hannah.

Sending all my love to you and your wife, from Canada ❤️

snippet.textDisplay:
You're a lovely human, and I wish you and Ella all the happiness in the entire world. 💜
That being said, your pain is incredibly valid. I could relate to a ton of what you said, and I see you, and I hear you. I'm sorry for the clouds of rejection from your dad and the immense pain you are in. We got you, Hannah. We're here for your victories, your joys, and your sorrows. 💜
